item.title: Five Minute GitHub Tutorial with RStudio - Simple!
item.description: What is a GitHub? Recently, I went to search for a few jobs in the tech industry and one thing stood out with each of the sites I visited. Everyone was asking “What’s your GitHub address?” Admittedly, I didn’t have one until just the other day. I posted this short five minute tutorial to get you started early! GitHub is a repository for version control hosting of coding projects and much more.

item.title: Add a Button To Excel to Run a Macro
item.description: Adding Button for GUI Interface. Now that you have a few macros under your belt (some from scratch, some recorded, and some cut/pasted from the internet), it’s time to make a user interface for them. In this tutorial, I will show you how to insert a simple button control to activate your macro. This is a very easy process and it will save you from having to explain to users how to get into the VBA editor.

item.title: VBA Convert XLSX to CSV Files - Entire Directory
item.description: Convert File Extensions. Sometimes, you find yourself converting one file extension to another for various reasons. Many software programs will not read files such as a .xlsx or .xlsm Excel file. They will, however, easily read a .csv file. In this tutorial, I will show you how to use an already created macro to convert an entire directory of files to a new file extensions almost instantly. Saves a tremendous amount of time using macros for this.

item.title: For Loops, Cells & Iterators with VBA
item.description: Cells and for loops. In this tutorial, we will take a lateral approach to ranges and instead, use cells. This quick 5 minute video will walk you through why cells are easier to work with when iterating through loops; specifically, for loops. In addition, this video shows you the value of the debugger when testing programs at runtime. In this tutorial you will learn the basics of: Cells instead of Range

item.title: 6 Steps to Link all .csv Files as Tables - Access / VBA
item.description: Ever want to link an entire directory of “*.csv" files to a Microsoft Access database? Manually, this could be tedious and exhausting. I will walk you through six easy steps to automate the process using VBA and allow you to link hundreds of files in seconds! (Also see video tutorial at the bottom) [caption id=“attachment_133” align=“alignnone” width=“300”]Relational table links - Microsoft Access[/caption] What typically happens, is the customer sends a daily Excel file and you store it in a directory for archival purposes.
